text: And so, again, remember that you have jungle primary, so you select just one person.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Anybody can run on jungle primary.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: There's no vetting process.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Bad news for Republicans, bad news for most people.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And then the rank-choice voting system allows for manipulation and exhausted ballots.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So people like my grandfather, who loved to vote, loved to be a participant in the process, will not vote for more than one person, but because of that could ultimately have their vote thrown out.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And if you look at the 2022 election and you look at all the people that voted for just one person and you add their votes back in, Sarah Palin wins.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: If all the people that voted for Nick Bagich voted for Sarah Palin second...
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Palin wins the election.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So what do you say to the people that want to sell to support and not fight ranked choice voting when they say, well, rank the red?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: I know what I say, but I want to hear what you say.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: So I think rank the red was a failure in its wording.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: It's rank all Republicans.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And so that's the best strategy to win with ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: But the problem that you have, even with this, and I'm a pretty respected person overall when it comes to this topic, and so when I go around and tell people it doesn't matter, the guys are still going to vote for just one person.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: That's just because that's just how they are, and that's a moral value thing.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: You're ignoring actual ground conditions with that.
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: But because of that, those people are going to end up costing us elections.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And so because the system isn't designed for people to do that.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And so we're going to cover these real quick.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So merits of ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: I want simple merits.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So this is what I broke it down.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Is it better?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Why?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Is it cheaper?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Why?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Is it faster?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: How?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Does it increase turnout?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Proof.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Does it eliminate spoiler candidates?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Proof.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Does it help third parties?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Proof.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And does it produce an absolute majority?
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: It doesn't do any of these things.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: It claims they do, but it doesn't do any of them.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And then, in fact, I've actually gotten in touch with the lieutenant governor and got all the details on the election.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And this was the most expensive election in Alaska's history.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: We spent 328% more with ranked choice voting election than we did any other election previously.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And from 2010 to 2020, our average spend was $3.3 million.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: We spent almost $11.1 million on ranked choice voting elections.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: $2.5 million went to the special election that shouldn't have happened.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: That was earlier when I said Don Young passed away.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: $2.5 million spent just because we added this special election little gamut.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: The regular election was $5 million, so just the regular election by itself was way more expensive than the $3.3 million.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And it cost $3.5 million just to buy the equipment and do all the software and everything else, all the training and stuff necessary.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: They said that ranked choice voting education was going to be $150,000 and end up being $3.1 million.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So they had to get a special appropriation from the legislature.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: So they spent an equivalent of one year's worth in an entire election just on ranked choice voting education.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And that was a 2,000% increase from their budgeted item.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: I don't really like the government blowing their budget by 2,000%.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: That's not really super cohesive with fiscal conservatism and things like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And so on top of all this, we have the lowest voter turnout in the history of the state.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: We added more electronic voting machines.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And we're the last state in the country for election results.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: I don't really see any benefit of using ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And I hope everyone on this call recognizes how dangerous this is.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And I'm not the only one.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: There's Secretary of State of Washington State who recently came out and said he was originally a proponent of ranked choice voting and he liked it.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: But, you know, he has a disabled daughter and he said that his disabled daughter, he was concerned about her and her ability to understand the system.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And so the secretary of state is a Democrat in Washington state is now against ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Secretary of state of Montana is Republicans against ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: The D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Democrats.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Democratic Party have sued the block ranked choice voting last year because they did not want it in D.C.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Gavin Newsom vetoed ranked choice voting from taking effect in California.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Former California Jerry Brown also against ranked choice voting.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Where did you see the Republicans in our own state with this?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: How's that gone?
speaker: SPEAKER_05

text: Oh, you know, I'm glad we have a little bit of time left.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: You know, the Alaska Republican Party, the local groups are very, very helpful in a lot of states.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: Kenai and Fairbanks and Mat-Su, they're great.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: But the actual state Republican Party was probably the most useless party
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: you know, hunk of trash I've ever dealt with, you know, they didn't do anything.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: And, you know, I've done, uh, I've asked, you know, I didn't really talk to him too much, but they didn't offer any support and offer any data.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: They didn't offer any, uh, financial, they didn't offer any volunteers.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: They've had nothing.
speaker: SPEAKER_08

text: They just left us to our own devices, and that's just not how you do things.

speaker: SPEAKER_08
